meta.title: IEC 62443-3-2 Security Risk Assessment for System Design

zones.name: Level 3 - SCADA DMZ
zones.description: Demilitarized zone (DMZ) hosting SCADA servers, historians, and engineering workstations. Provides controlled access between enterprise network and control system operations.
zones.typical_assets: HMI servers, Historian databases, Engineering workstations, Application servers, Asset management systems

zones.name: Level 2 - Area Supervisory Control
zones.description: Area supervisory control containing manufacturing operations management and area control systems. Direct supervision of Level 1 controllers.
zones.typical_assets: Supervisory controllers, Area HMI, DCS servers, Local historians, MES interfaces

zones.name: Level 1 - Basic Control
zones.description: Basic control zone containing PLCs, DCS controllers, and other devices performing direct process control functions.
zones.typical_assets: PLCs, DCS controllers, RTUs, Local I/O modules, Smart instruments

zones.name: Level 0 - Physical Process
zones.description: Physical process zone containing sensors, actuators, and field devices directly interacting with the physical process.
zones.typical_assets: Sensors, Actuators, Field instruments, Smart transmitters, Motor drives

zones.name: Level 4 - Site Business Planning and Logistics
zones.description: Site business planning and logistics zone containing systems that manage production scheduling, operational management, and plant-level business functions. Bridges operational technology and enterprise IT.
zones.typical_assets: MES servers, ERP connectors, Production schedulers, Plant databases, Business intelligence systems, Quality management systems

zones.name: Level 5 - Enterprise Network
zones.description: Enterprise network zone containing corporate IT systems, business applications, and external connectivity. Standard IT security practices apply, with additional controls for any connections to lower Purdue levels.
zones.typical_assets: Corporate ERP, Email servers, Office applications, Finance systems, Cloud connectors, Internet gateways

conduits.name: Firewall - Level 2 to Level 3
conduits.description: Stateful industrial firewall with deep packet inspection (DPI) and protocol validation. Enforces allowlist of permitted communications between supervisory control and SCADA DMZ.

conduits.name: Data Diode - Level 1 to Level 3
conduits.description: Hardware-enforced unidirectional data flow from process control network to DMZ. Used for one-way historian data replication and monitoring without exposing control systems to return traffic.

conduits.name: Internal Zone Connection - Level 1 Controllers
conduits.description: Switched network within Level 1 zone connecting PLCs and controllers. Security enforced at zone boundary rather than internally. Should be monitored for anomalous behavior.

conduits.name: Enterprise Firewall - Level 3 to Level 4
conduits.description: Enterprise-grade firewall with application-layer inspection between the SCADA DMZ and site business planning zone. Enforces strict data flow policies for MES/ERP integration, allowing only approved application protocols and data exchanges.

conduits.name: Business Gateway - Level 4 to Level 5
conduits.description: Gateway connecting site business planning systems to the corporate enterprise network. Provides controlled data exchange for production reporting, ERP synchronization, and business intelligence while preventing direct enterprise access to operational systems.

conduits.name: Secure Remote Access Gateway
conduits.description: Dedicated remote access infrastructure with multi-factor authentication, session recording, and jump server architecture. Provides controlled access for vendor maintenance, remote engineering, and emergency support while enforcing least-privilege and time-limited sessions.

conduits.name: Field Bus - Level 0 to Level 1
conduits.description: Industrial field bus networks (Modbus, PROFIBUS, HART, Foundation Fieldbus) connecting field devices to controllers. Typically lacks built-in authentication or encryption. Security depends on physical isolation and zone boundary protections.

flows.data_flow_description: Process data, alarms, and commands between Level 2 controllers and Level 3 SCADA systems
One-way historian data replication from process controllers to SCADA DMZ for monitoring and analysis
Process variable readings from sensors/transmitters and control outputs to actuators via industrial field bus protocols
Control commands, setpoint changes, and process data between basic controllers and area supervisory systems
Aggregated production data and alarm summaries from area supervisory control to SCADA DMZ for historian archival

flows.target_zone_name: Level 4 - Site Business Planning and Logistics
flows.data_flow_description: Production reports, quality data, and operational metrics from SCADA DMZ to MES and business planning systems

flows.source_zone_name: Level 4 - Site Business Planning and Logistics
flows.data_flow_description: ERP data synchronization, production scheduling, and business intelligence data exchange between site operations and corporate enterprise
Remote engineering sessions, vendor maintenance access, and emergency support connections via authenticated and monitored gateway

reference_architectures.name: Purdue Model
reference_architectures.description: Standard ICS network segmentation model with 6 levels (0-5) defining separation between enterprise IT and operational technology
reference_architectures.industry_applicability: Manufacturing, Process Control, Energy, Water Treatment

reference_architectures.name: ISA-95 Enterprise-Control System Integration
reference_architectures.description: Standard for integrating enterprise and control systems with focus on data flow and functional hierarchy
